snippet.title: Training models of shape from sets of examples
snippet.description:
Training models of shape from sets of examples
by Cj. Taylor, D. H. Cooper, J. Graham \- Proc. BMVC92, Springer-Verlag , 1992
"... .Graham Department of Medical Biophysics University of Manchester Oxford Road Manchester M13 9PT email: bim ..."
Abstract \- Cited by 153 (4 self) \- Add to MetaCart
A method for building flexible shape models is presented in which a shape is represented by a set of labelled points. The technique determines the statistics of the points over a collection of example shapes. The mean positions of the points give an average shape and a number of modes of variation are determined describing the main ways in which the example shapes tend to deform from the average. In this way allowed variation in shape can be included in the model. The method produces a compact flexible 'Point Distribution Model' with a small number of linearly independent parameters, which can be used during image search. We demonstrate the application of the Point Distribution Model in describing two classes of shapes. 1

snippet.title: THE MANCHESTER INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SOCIETY: AN HISTORICAL OVERVIEW

THE MANCHESTER INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SOCIETY: AN HISTORICAL OVERVIEW
by Ralph Darlington
"... on Nissan, Honda, Jaguar, ICI, Manchester Airport, United Biscuits, Birmingham NHS Trust, and Tesco ..."
Abstract \- Add to MetaCart
Over the last decade or so some commentators have suggested the apparent transformation of employment that has occurred since the 1970s and 1980s – such as the demise of manufacturing industry and growth of the private services sector, the decline in the level of trade union membership and collective bargaining
